content.title: Kaz. Brodziński jako pierwszy tłumacz Goethego w Polsce

results:
Based on the search results, I found information about Kazimierz Brodziński's 1822 Polish translation of Goethe's "The Sorrows of Young Werther" (Die Leiden des jungen Werthers).

In 1822 Kazimierz Brodziński translated The Sorrows of Young Werther into Polish. This appears to have been the first Polish translation of Goethe's famous work.

The search results indicate that:

1. There is a scholarly article titled "Kaz. Brodziński jako pierwszy tłumacz Goethego w Polsce" (Kaz. Brodziński as the first translator of Goethe in Poland) published in the literary journal "Pamiętnik Literacki" in 1928, which suggests Brodziński was indeed the first to translate Goethe's work into Polish.

2. Die Leiden des jungen Werthers (The Sorrows of Young Werther) is an epistolary novel written by Johann Wolfgang von Goethe, published in 1774. Along with Schiller's The Robbers, it is considered the most important work of the so-called Sturm und Drang ("storm and stress") period and pre-Romanticism.

3. Kazimierz Brodziński (1791-1835) was a literary critic, aesthetician, historian of Polish literature, university lecturer, poet, translator, and publicist. In 1822 he took the chair of Polish literature at the University of Warsaw, which was the same year he translated Werther.

This translation was significant as it introduced this influential work of German Romanticism to Polish readers and contributed to the spread of "Werterism" (werteryzm) in Polish literature and culture.
